column1:
Melkim,"2010-06-24T12:51:08.763Z","So, whatâ€™s new in the 8097 compared to 6209 from 2006?","

Overall the new 8097 is a copy of the already existing 6209. New colouring and new mini figures, otherwise only small differences. Mostly new or changed weapon systems. When it comes to building its pretty much the same set, although with some very nice changes.

column2: I got the new 8097 version of this death bringing vessel delivered a few weeks ago. The first thing that hits you is the size of the box. It feels huge for a 573 piece model. Nice box overall with nice and inspiring pictures. Even tough I personally don&rsquo
column3: t like the Clone logo of these new series, the box is very nice to watch. Well, not as delightful as the 6210 Jabba&rsquo
column4: s Sail Barge box, with its structured printing, but still very nice.

column2: Building

column1: New exiting parts are the half circle at the side of the ship. Two quarter circles form a nice smooth shape and are much fairer to the film original. The tail also has a rounded smooth look. When it comes to details I personally think that the older version beats the new one. For example the new droid arms on the wings give a sloppy impression and the new storage doors to fit small hand guns don&rsquo
column2: t look as integrated as they did in the 6209.
A very nice new feature is the hidden semi automatic missile on top of the ship. You can actually fire away all four missiles by using a &ldquo
column3: handle&rdquo
column4: . This concealed weapon has saved Boba Fett many times and it takes playing to another level. Another improvement is the rear cargo door, which fits Han Solo carbonated. Just open and load him in, then get away before Lando, Leia and Chewie catches up!

column2: To come to a conclusion, the new 8097 is totally worth buying. This model is very fun and challenging to build, with almost no repetitive building. The new nice look and mini figures along with the new play ability makes it a very nice model for both collectors and players.
Pros:
Cons:

column1: • Stickers are always a big no no. Why Lego? Why? Give us Pre printed.
• Missing mini figures: Lando and one of those carbonate-working-pigs.

column2: new&rdquo
column3: weapon looks very lame.

column1: sudorum,"2010-07-24T17:12:36.167Z","A Must Have Star Wars Set","If you're a die-hard lego Star Wars fan, you just can't &nbsp
column2: pass up this set. The reason?-the minifigures. The new Boba Fett is a great improvement over the original. He is incredibly movie accurate, and actually has a face under his helmet (whether it's a made-up one or not). Bossk is just as grand and is truly one of the best SW minifigures. The Slave I is a good improvement over the last two versions, although its construction is very similar in some parts to the 2006 version. What separates it from the previous version is the inclusion of accurate minifigures. Anyone remember Dengar? Anyway, you can stash the carbonate-preserved Han Solo in the boarding ramp of the ship, launch flick fire missiles from two compartments located on the side, and also fire a semi-automatic flick fire missile system in the middle of the ship. My only complaints would be the usual expensive price and the carbonate, which doesn't have a covering to conceal Han's back side.&nbsp
column3:
,FALSE,4,5,5,4,3 Buckbrick","2010-07-30T09:30:46.447Z","Everybody loves a Slave 1","

No matter how many versions and re-releases, everyone loves a Slave 1. It has got to be one of the best mid-sized SW sets out there. Having owned the previous highly-rated 6209, I had some misgivings of getting another reiteration initially. But it looks cool when placed side by side. I can only imagine all 3 Slave 1's together! Apart from the price, it is a great set.

column2: Evolved but fairly similar design: with new parts such as the dark green quarter dome, the front fairing can be rendered more faithfully. I love the new front, but prefer the more streamlined rear of the 6209. However, the new does look closer to the actual ship in terms of how the hull plates appear. Perhaps that's why the 8097 looks a little stunted in length.

column1: Built: Built is about 70% similar to the 6209. The only difference here is the weapons mechanism. But still as fresh and exciting.

Minifigs: All I can say about the minifigs is WOW. While some would hate the new paint scheme of Boba Fett, it works well when you see the actual minifig. Bossk is awesome with the yellow and fan-fav sand green. You also get a new Han Solo with plain brown legs and an ingenious new carbonite mould, where you can stick Han in.

Weapons system: I find the new weapons an underwhelming downgrade from the previous Slave 1. The 6209 was simply bristling with enough firepower to take on the likes of the Imperial starfleet, even in Lego form. This time, you get a rack of rockets, a flick-fire missile or 2... I'm afraid that's all you're gonna get this time, Boba. I guess even bounty hunters feel the pinch of the recent economic crisis.
Playability: I'm way pass that stage. But I'm sure the kids-at-heart will get a kick out of swooshing this around.
Price: Inflation happens even in the SW universe.
column2: Ugghh...&nbsp

column1: <div>So should you get this set? It can be subjective - just like a Toyota car, it's another face-lifted Slave 1. On the other hand,&nbsp
column2: I know there are folks out there who do not regret owning both Jango's and Boba's Slave 1's. It's the same thing here. I bit the bullet and got this over the iPad. So that's saying something, I guess.",TRUE,5,4,4,4,3

column1:
J0rgen,"2010-06-29T13:13:02.597Z","Put captain Solo in the cargo hold, or just stash him under the entry ramp, either way's good.","

I picked this up in
column2: the LEGO shop at Billund Airport last Friday, on my way home from LEGOLAND, that means I got the set a little early, since it's due for a July release. I built it while taking a break from the build of my newly aquired Death Star(which I'll probably review at some point) and it was a fairly easy build, compared to the formentioned Death Star. I previously own Jango Fett's Slave I from 2002, and I recognize a lot of elements from that set: The ship's base is excactly the same, only with new colors, but it's supposed to be the same ship, so I guess that's allright. The cockpit is the same, but this one isn't as dark and has four horrible stickers. This design is very smooth, compared to Jango's more rough design and the engines on this one really outshines Jango's! The back of this edition looks excactly like the real Slave I! The thing I really miss in the Slave ships is some interior, the old version had some, if the guns were on the outside and you removed the large container you had a narrow corridor leading to the cockpit, which was notably larger than this one, fitting both
column3: Boba and his father. In the new version, the only way to enter the ship is by placing Boba directly in the cockpit, the rest of the ship is completely filled up with the weapon systems, the entrance is even blocked! The entrance is definitely the worst part about this ship, at the top it reaches four bricks tall, that means the doorway's only three bricks tall, not nearly enough room for a minifigure(especially the new Boba Fett, with his jetpack and ""antenna"", he's&nbsp
column4: one of&nbsp
column5: the tallest minifigures I've got). It's not only the doorway that's too low, the ramp leading up to it is way too steep. And then there's the problem that it's blocked by the weapon system. The reason the ramp is so elevated is that instead of actually having a cargo hold inside the ship to put captain Solo in, the designers decided they'd just make room under the ramp and put the carbon-freezed Solo in there instead. So, that was the main negative thing about this set! Now, to the weapon systems, even though they take up an awful lot of space, they're the most advanced, firing missiles I've seen in a LEGO set ever! I'm obviously not talking about the blue flick-fire missiles located in the ships front, but the orange rack of re-loading missiles located in the ships center. You fire them by pressing one of the engines, located on the rear side of the ship, after you've opened a hatch in the ship's front. The beauty of this mecanism is that once you've fired a missile, it instantly prepares another for launch, which it will repeat until you've fired all four missiles. A slight improvent over the missiles from Jango's Slave I! There's also the laser cannons, they don't fire anything but imaginary lasers of course, but they rotate very smoothly. Despite the lack of proper interior, the ship has quite a lot of storage space, in addition to the compartment where Han Solo is put, there's a safe built into each side of the ship and in the front, behind the lasers, there's an compartment containing an empty crate. Finally, before talking about the amazing minifigures, I must&nbsp
column6: mention the color scheme. Even though the balance between gray and dark green is good, the dark red for the base does not fit, the last version of Boba's Slave I had a brown base, which looked way better! Then it's time for the minifigures, Boba Fett is AWESOME! Plain and simply, his utility belt is now printed on the torso, there's a trophy from a defeated wookie and his armor look's better than before. His jetpack is detachable, as well as his helmet and the helmet has the detachable target system, previously used for the ""Clone Wars"" clones. He also has his worn out cape over his left shoulder, the only thing I didn't like at first was the sand blue arms and legs, but when seeing the minifigure in real life I thought it looked good. I have prepared grey arms and legs though, so I'll see wether I'll replace them or not. Bosssk has a cool, new head and has a movie accurate spacesuit. Han Solo has one of this new heads(with an&nbsp
column8: in his eyes), but I guess that's the future of Star Wars LEGO, luckily I have plenty of real Solo heads to replace it with, so I'll do fine. His shirt is nice, but could use some ironing. The carbon freezed Han Solo is great, especially compared to the old printed version. Han Solo fits in the back, which is a pretty nice feature.

column1: • Stickers, my sticker sheet had been bent so they almost peel of.

• The cockpit doesn't rotate in the movies, but it does look cool. Also, it's possible to fix quite easily, so it's not really that much of a con.
    • ",TRUE,5,5,4,5,4

FLAME,"2010-07-08T00:02:38.307Z","AWRRRRRSOME","

This set is quite nice. Not many new parts here, except for the cockpit window. There's a lot of space in the set, but due to the turning seat, all that space is wasted. For some reason
column2: LEGO really love remaking old sets these days. The new boba fett minifigure is OK, because there are too much different colors on him.&nbsp
column3: On to the pros and cons:

column1:
Carl,"2010-10-01T00:10:17.317Z","Best Slave 1 so far!","This is a really awesome Lego set! I bought it just yesterday for $140 NZD (a little pricey, but the original price was $200, so I can't really grovel about a $60 discount) and it was done in a matter of hours after it getting through the front door. After having enviously watched my brother build all the other Slave 1s, I was insanely excited about finally building one of my own. And man! I was NOT disappointed!

Pros
  • New Boba Fett
  • Bossk (I've always like him)
  • New Han Solo in Carbonite
  • Awesome flick fire mechanism
  • Rotating wings connected to Boba's seat
  • Cool colours
  • The whole ship design
Cons
  • Old flick fire missiles
  • Not much room inside the ship
  • Nothing to go with the ship (eg:Landing Platform)

Overall this is a Lego Star Wars set that I would definitely
column2: recommend to any Lego collector, and I am very happy with my purchase.

column1:
hobohopper,"2010-08-14T01:54:40.233Z","Great set for fans of Boba Fett, but like everyone has already said, it is extremely overpriced.","I have to say, this is probably one of the most well designed sets of the year. The only thing that should be holding anyone back from buying this set is the price.

Let's start with the minifigures.

Boba Fett: HOLY COW. This has to be one of the greatest minifigures of all time. The helmet, the detail, the jet pack, the everything is wonderfully accurate. Some may say this is more aciton figure than lego minifig, but i disagree. Sure the blaster and the silencer look a bit awkward, but if that bothers you just take it off. Looking at the pics, it seems as if the jet pack and the cape separates his shoulder from his neck far too much, but rest assured, once you have this figure in hand, you will notice that the helmet sits much closer to the shoulders than the pictures depict. Boba Fett looks flawless

Bossk: This guy's pretty cool too. Brand new head is accurate, and hard plastic, unlike Yoda or Plo Koon. This means you dont have to worry about paint chipping! He makes for a fun foe for Boba Fett to fight against.

Han Solo: new face, new torso, but not much else to say. He looks a bit better than previous incarnations, especially the face. He fits into the carbonite piece via pegs that his hands can grab.

Carbonite: Not techincally a minifigure, but this thing's wonderfully detailed. All the printing is...well printing. No stickers here =] great texture and a detailed molding of Captain Solo trapped in there. This is worlds better than the previous incnarnation.

The Ship:

At first glance, it looks alot like 6209. But fret not. It shares the shape, but the design is more different than you think. The rapid fire flick missles are much different from the single spring missle in 6209. They fire well too, and as a bonus, the structure of the mechanism serves as braces that hold the entire ship together. The mechanism is pure technic, which, combined with the bricks that make up the ship, creates one of the sturdiest, most solid starwars sets ive seen in a long time. You can knock someone out with this ship! (but please, don't).
column2:
The cockpit rotates with the wings, which are gravity powered. It gets the job done alrite.
The interior of the cockpit, however, is a huge mess up. There is literally nothing in here beside a brick that the Fett man sits on, and a 2x1 flat printed control panel. Theres so much space in here, i dont know why lego couldnt have designed a less spartan cockpit. I've modded mine extensively, as im sure most of you will too.

Along the sides of the ship are various compartments. There are useless flick fires that u can fold out. Atleast it looks cool, if not much else. The compartments are small, Fett's gun will not fit in here. But, the cockpit is so enormous and empty, Fett can jsut hold on to his gun.
column3:
You can stow away captain Solo in the cargo hold with ease. He stays in plays, not much rattles during play. However, the cargo hold is inaccurate. The previous slave 1's got it right, this one does not simply because the new carbonite mold wouldnt fit into the ship. So, the cargo hold is actually in the ship's bottom skirt, the dark red part (sorry, i cant think of a better way to describe it). You cant recreate that famous ""put captain solo in the cargo hold"" scene =[

The entire ship is probably the most move accurate slave 1 to date. The ship is aboslutely gorgeous, a great display model. The colors look beautiful. The dark red, when contrasted against the green, look almost brown. I feel that the stickers need not be applied. The ship looks accurate without them, so those of you who are complaining, just dont apply them.

Once again, this ship has very few flaws. The only gripe, is the price. Everyone's been saying it, but the ship is not worth $80. In my opinion, $60 is a fair price. $70 is pushing it, but not completely unreasonable. $80 just feels like Lego is trying to cash in on Boba Fett's popularity, knowing that no matter how expensive the set is, the Boba fans out there will still buy it. Shame on you Lego. This is a perfect set, at an unreasonable price.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,3

column1:
TangDynasty,"2010-10-31T23:10:45.62Z","Great set but the price is a killer!","We started getting into the whole Lego Star Wars thing only last year and there are many older sets that we did not get a chance to buy. It was nice to re-issue some old sets with in my opinion, better minifigs. But the price, is way to much for some of the sets. In Singapore, this set's retail price is $199.90! Crazy amount of money for way too few pieces. But, I guess that is the trend of the Star Wars sets in general. So is the ship worth it and are the minifigs worth it?

We have not build the old Slave I so the building experience are based on a first timer. It is pretty fun to build and there are obvious improvement to the look of the ship when compare to the old one. But for the price, it could have had more details or parts to make it more complete. Somehow, it seemed a bit unfinished, like in the cock pit area and the wings. The ramp door at the back is a bit fragile with the pieces came off pretty easily. We can't really describe it but we felt a bit anti-climatic towards the end of the building like, ""That's it? This for $199.90!?""

On the other hand, the new colours are nice and the ship's design is cool! And, the minifigs that come with the set are gorgeous. The drool factor is high for the minifigs here... The print details are really good on the minifigs.

Here are the pros and cons...

Pros:

- The colours for the Slave 1 are nice.
- Bossk (Nice)
- Boba Fett (Very nice)
- Han Solo and the new carbonite (Very nice indeed)
column2:
Cons:

- The price...
- The old boring flick missles...
- The price!

Overall, we had a great time building it as it is a first for us. The fact is that it is one of the more iconic ships in Star Wars adds to the value of the set and make it a must-have for us. The ship is nicely designed and the new colours are good. What pushes this set that may justify the hefty price are the minifigs. However, if the minifigs are not the ones that you are going after, then it may be wise to think twice before parting the money for the set.

Thanks for reading!


",TRUE,5,5,5,5,3

column1:
desire4one,"2010-08-03T01:20:00.703Z","Everything But Cupholders","

It is the ship that all bounty hunters wish they had, and the ship all do-gooders dread...it is...Slave 1.
column2: This is the 3rd time this ship as seen release, and I think this is the best looking to date.

column1: The ship itself is quite big, and probably the closest to scale.
column2: You could really envision Fett flying this thing around the Kessel Run.&nbsp
column3: It has good stability and a weighty feel.&nbsp
column4: The blaster cannons look good and the hidden missles in the tail give it that ""Fett"" feel.&nbsp
column5: The semi-automatic missle system is a bit shaky.&nbsp
column6: Shoot it too fast and it's gonna fall apart.&nbsp
column7: A one of a kind cockkpit window.&nbsp
column8: Sadly, it's so big it will likely not see use outside of the instruction manual.&nbsp
column9: Lots of storage sections for hiding and smuggling goods.&nbsp
column10: I could see this becoming a mobile base of operations for young bounty hunters the world over.&nbsp
column11: That being said, all the interior space is used up on the missle firing system.&nbsp
column12: Just once, I'd like to see Lego design a set with the INTERIOR of a model in mind.&nbsp
column13: Then again, these are designed for little guys (and gals).&nbsp

column1: The minifigs are the shining point in this set.
column2: Boba Fett may be the best looking minifigure I've seen thus far.&nbsp
column3: He is extremely detailed and accurate to the films.&nbsp
column4: Lego knows this and that's why they're price gauging the set.&nbsp
column5: Bossk is great too, with a head piece far superior to those produced these days.&nbsp
column6: Throw in a Han fig and Carbonite piece and your good to replay Empire.&nbsp

column1: Lego also threw in an accessory sprue, which is nice to see.
column2: Visor, Kama, Antena, and&nbsp
column3: 2, count em, 2 Blaster&nbsp
column4: Pistols.&nbsp
column5: They should embrace this idea and add it to more sets in the future.

column2: A great centerpiece that can take a beating.
Terrific figs and in my opionion the best ones thus far.

column1: <li>The ship can shoot 4 missles in a row.&nbsp
column2: Slave 1 doesn't need to reload.&nbsp
column3: It's Slave 1.

column1: <li>The price is REALLY hard to stomach.&nbsp
column2: It is extremely overpriced.&nbsp
column3: This set should have retailed for around $50-$60.&nbsp
column4: If you're buying this, your a diehard Fett fan, and Lego's banking on that.

column1: <li>The interior of the ship is wasted on the missle system.&nbsp
column2: Sure it can shoot missles, but nobody's hitching a ride on this one.

column1: I must restate that this set is extremely overpriced.
column2: If you're pulling your wallet out for this one, like it or not, you're paying for the minifigs and the allure that is Boba Fett.&nbsp
column3:
If you're thinking of buying this for your little Lego fan at home, look else where, where you can get much better bang for your buck.

",TRUE,4,4,4,4,2

column1:
Blackicep8ntball,"2010-08-06T16:51:06.143Z","This set would be a very good set if it were worth the money. And why, why, why more stickers?","
Slave I: A Buyer's Guide

Welcome to my review of the newest edition to the Slave I family. I hope this will be helpful to those contemplating the purchase. I'll start with the set's strenghts, and then move on to its weaknesses.

As anyone familiar with the Star Wars Slave I will immediately notice, this version most clearly reflects the movie version of the Slave, at least as far as colors and shape go. The dark green pieces are the biggest improvement in this area over the 2006 version. In addition, the Boba Fett figure is truly a beauty. The other figures are nice additions: Bossk has a solid plastic head, (which I prefer to the rubbery heads some aliens have nowadays), and Solo's carbonite block is very nicely molded (be aware that it has no back, however! Solo just sorta hangs in there, and is clearly visible if you turn the block over). The set is not difficult to build, has some useful parts to build your Lego collection, and has a fantastic rapid-fire missile mechanism. It's honestly a very neat little set.
However, this set has many weak points that, in my opinion, solidly undermine its strengths. The most glaring issue: it's vastly over-priced. For a comparison:

- 2010: 8097 Slave I - 573 pieces, $79.99 (US), 3 minifigs
- 2006: 6209 Slave I - 537 pieces, $49.99 (US), 4 minifigs
That's nearly double the price for only 36 more pieces (which are primarily small technic parts), and one less minifigure.

Another issue I have is with the multitude of STICKERS. The quality of Lego stickers has increased in the past few years, but these guys are just plain difficult to put on straight, and I'm in graduate school. I can't imagine 9-15 year olds having an easy time. Moreover, the stickers tend to peel off after years of use. For a $30 increase, one would hope Lego could provide the printed parts as it did in the earlier versions (i.e. 7153 Jango Fett's Slave I).

Finally, some of the smaller squables I have with this set: the missile firing mechanism, while nifty, protrudes into the cabin area (simply an aesthetic issue). Also, Boba Fett must hold on to his gun, because this ship has no storage compartment that will fit it! (Older models had plenty of storage). In addition, this version's cabin seating is the most scant of any versions - just a block with a control panel (compare, again, to the seating from Jango's slave I). And lastly, Han Solo gets stored under the ramp in the back, not up in the ship as the older versions had.

So, in summary:
Pros:
- Most movie-accurate colors so far
- Fantastic Boba Fett minifigure, neat Bossk figure and Solo in carbonite
- Missile firing mechanism is cool
- relatively straightforward and fun build

Cons:
- Price: maybe $59.99, but not worth $79.99!
- Stickers: they're difficult to apply, not permanent, give it a cheap feel, etc...
- a few aesthetic issues (e.g. missile mechanism protruded into the cabin, lack of detail in seating, etc.)
- insufficient storage capacity (Where does Boba's gun go?!?!)

My recommendation: Pass on this set. I bought it to complete my collection (I have all the old Slave Is). Unless you're a hardcore collector though, this set just doesn't provide the value it should, and if fewer people buy the model, maybe The Lego Group will get the message.

Thanks for taking the time to read my review. Until next time....
",TRUE,3,4,5,4,2
abertr,"2010-08-24T17:18:41.44Z","oh well","I love the characters in this set. &nbsp
column2: They are all great in there own ways. &nbsp
column3:
I do find it interesting that Bossk is included since he and Boba don't get along...

The ship:
Not much to add from the other reviews.
column4: The missile firing system is well designed and similar in structure to the attack shuttle set with Mace Windu. &nbsp
column5:
The build wasn't to bad and the hidden flick missiles have good assemblies.

Like many others I was disappointed with the interior of the ship.
column6: It rotates with the wings to have Boba ""see"" while flying which is cool, but they really really needed to improve the details. &nbsp
column7: I did some heavy modifications to create a console and effects for the ship to help improve the playability. &nbsp

I am going to conquer the hinged wings next to make them a little more appealing.

A classic ship with a great character.

column1: LegoAficionado,"2010-08-12T20:22:45.11Z","Lego has outdone themselves again: An AWESOME Set, but another high price...","This is the last Star Wars set that I bought recently. And at $79.99 it is pretty costly. But what you get with it is not only in my opinion the best version of the iconic Slave I, but also the best versions of the iconic Boba Fett, Bossk, Han Solo, and Han Solo in Carbonite.&nbsp
column2:
My first Slave I was the original 1998 version, which in comparison to this version is very small. Then I got the 2002 Jango Fett Slave I version. When the Boba Fett Salve I was rereleased in 2006, I decided to pass up on it, and I regretted that I did until I bought this set. Let's see what has changed for the better and worse, and how does this set stand with its other counterparts?

The Minifigs:
Lego has been doing really great this summer with releasing new and improved versions of previously old lego minifigs. This set is decked out with some of the best minifigs I have ever seen in a model. Let's start with Boba Fett.

Boba Fett: The best version of a Mandalorian Bounty Hunter yet. I am so glad
column3: Lego decided to separate the jetpack from the helmet in this&nbsp
column4: version,&nbsp
column5: because it truly makes the minifig realistic in comparison to the movies.&nbsp
column6: Also the shoulder cape is a very nice touch along with the color scheme.&nbsp
column7:
All of Boba Fett's armor is a sea foam green while his arms and legs are a tan blue color. In general very aesthetic.

Bossk: This bounty hunter is very rare, and all together fits perfectly with this
column8:
set.
Han Solo: This Han Solo is very detailed and the carbonite container is perfect,
column9: because Han just clicks right into the bottom of the container. Yes, the&nbsp
column10: container has no bottom but Han Solo fits so well inside, that you really won't notice.&nbsp
column11:
The Build:

Building the Slave I should not be so different by now, right? Well in comparison to the first two versions of the Slave I, it is very different. In comparison to the 2006 version, not so much. The main difference this Slave I has amongst every other version is the main function of the ship and the more slick and movie accurate detailed look to it.
column12:
The build is more challenging that most of the other sets, but that is because the ship is very big. It is a good foot in width and length, and a good 5 inches in depth. The build takes place over the course of 3 bags and 2 instruction booklets, but this only makes the build more organized than just having a bunch of pieces dumped around.

The main function of the set is a flickfire missile contraption housed in the center of the ship, just below the cockpit. This is the exact same place that the 2006 version had the large trigger missile located. In my opinion, the flickfire mechanic works very well and I do enjoy this feature. On the sides of the ship are two more flickfire missiles and those unfortunately are a little harder to work properly, but they still work.
column13:
The ship has numerous storage compartments, two on each side of the ship as well as the main cargo hold for Han Solo to be stored. The Carbonite container fits perfectly into the cargo hold and overall, the storage units are very nice. My only gripe with these storage containers is that there really isn't anything to put into them. Sure you could just stuff some pieces there, but there are no extra blasters to store. Anyway...

The look of the Slave I, as I have said before, is the best. Everything looks smoother and slick. All the pieces work together and the color scheme fits exactly to what the movie version Slave I looks like. Compared to the 2006 model, this Slave I has dark red and green pieces rather than mostly Light green and brown pieces. The red and green also give the Slave I more of that rusting aged looked to it as well, which makes sense.
column14: The only problem with the ship that I found was the the seating for Boba Fett is very minimal and could have been elaborated like the 2002 model of the Slave I. Also Bossk does not have a seat in the cockpit, but this can easily be solved since there is are lots of spaces for him to sit deeped within the cockpit.
column16: I was very excited to build this set when I got it. In the end, I am very happy I have added this model to my collection, because not only is it one of my favorite Star Wars Vehicles, but because it is overall a great set.
column17:
Pros:

-Very Slick and Detailed Slave I, the best one yet (in my opinion)
-Great Flickfire mechanism
-Amazing Boba Fett Minifig, very detailed and just plain awesome
-Very nice Bossk figure
-Best Han Solo carbonite yet
-Lost of playability

Cons:
-The price of $79.99 (anyone could have seen this one coming)
column18: -The storage units have nothing to store...why?
column19: -The cockpit is not as elaborate as previous versions (mostly wish it was like
column21:
the 2002 model)

Overall- I thoroughly enjoyed building and playing with this set. Though it is about $80 dollars and you only get 573 pieces for it in comparison to other pricier sets with more pieces, this Slave I is the best version yet and I do not think Lego is planning on releasing another version anytime soon.
column22: What you get is a great set with an awesome flickfire mechanism, amazing deatil in both the ship and figures, and tons of playability to reenact your favorite star wars moments.
column23:
In the end, if you have the money or you can get over the fact it costs quite a bit, then buy this set. If not, you might be missing out on a really good set. So I give this version of the Slave I a 5/5!

",TRUE,5,5,5,5,3

David1971,"2011-01-08T16:59:23.45Z","I'm afraid I was rather disappointed...","

Everyone seems to love this set. But for the price, I'm sorry, I don't find it to be that amazing. It's a good sturdy ship, well designed, and a good match for the iconic ship seen (briefly) in the movies. The Boba Fett minifig is, again, iconic, and very nicely done. And you get two other minifigs, a normal Han Solo and the unusual Bossk. So the three minifigs are good.
The ship is pleasingly solid, and has
column2: quite a good number of&nbsp
column3: little doors and hatches which are very&nbsp
column4: nice. There's room to put Han-in-carbonite in the back, and it's clever how the wing things rotate depending whether it's vertical or horizontal.

column1: But much of the interior is taken up with an overcomplicated, not very exciting mechanism for launching the tiresome flick-fire missiles ... I think it would have been nicer to have had a proper spaceship interior with seats and computer panels. After all, there's not even room for poor old Bossk to sit down.

In 2009, there were two sets around this price point, set #7754, Home One Mon Calimari Star Cruiser, and set #8038, The Battle of Endor. They both came with lots of minifigs and loads of playability. There was so much you could do with each of those sets once you'd built them. Whereas here ... it's a sort-of impressive object, especially for Star Wars fans, but it doesn't offer that much fun.
If you want a very well-made Lego model of Slave I, and a Boba Fett minifig, then this will make you very happy. It couldn't be better, if that's what you want.

If, like me, you like Star Wars and you love Lego, and you like a good fun set, and swooshable spaceships, and you like to get a number of interesting minifigs when you're spending Â£80 - and you like them to at least have somewhere to sit down (!!) -
column2: then this isn't necessarily the best set ever.

column1:
I suppose, in the end, you get different kinds of sets for different kinds of people. This one, for me, took things a bit too seriously.

",TRUE,3,4,3,3,3

THX_1138,"2011-12-26T22:21:58.4Z","A bit overpriced, but great anyway","

I had had Jango Fett's Slave I, but this was the first version of Boba Fett's that I ever got. My opinion of its value may be a little skewed in favor of the set since I got it for $15 off on Amazon.

Parts

Not bad, I suppose. You get some pretty cool ones, like the dark green quarter circles and the dark red shell pieces. This is also the first set to have the trans-clear windscreen.

Minifigures

Although there aren't as many as I'd want in an $80 set (I would've really loved a Bespin guard, or maybe even a new Dengar), the ones it has are really good. The new Boba Fett is a major improvement, but printed arms and legs would've really made it awesome. Bossk is a great figure too, but not as iconic of a character. Han's new face is way better than the original (never liked his old face at all), and his torso is pretty good. The new Han in carbonite piece is far better than the old 2x1x5 brick from the older sets.

The build

Pretty good, and not too repetitive.

The completed model

Very cool looking. The size is decent, and the colors are good. I don't care for flick-fire mechanisms, but at least this one doesn't compromise the ship's aesthetics. The only real complaint I have is the overly simplified cockpit, but it can easily be fixed.

Summary

Get it, especially if you don't have any previous versions, but try to find a lower price. On a side note, I really hope they release a new Jango Fett's Slave I
column2:
some time soon.

",TRUE,5,4,4,5,3

column1:
Huge_Nerd,"2011-03-07T13:14:58.957Z","I'm a...Slave...for you!","

I have been wanting this set for a long time, but I couldn't justify the price. Lo and behold, I found it for 30% off and rationalization took over!
This is my first Slave 1 and the largest set piece-wise I have ever owned (I have a castle with 435 pieces that I have had since childhood). Let me say, I am not disappointed at all.
column2: Ok, enough with the personal gushing, onto the set itself.

column1: The ship looks very movie accurate. I love the color scheme much better than pictures of previous releases. It is also
column2: rock solid&nbsp
column3: which is nice. I think it could possibly be used as a hammer. The rotating wings and pilot seat are a nice touch as well. I like the pull out flick-fire missiles and especially the semi-autmatic missile system--it is loads of fun! The ship has nice little storage areas for extra weapons. I consider the one in the ""chin"" of the ship to be Boba Fett's trash can. Han in carbonite stores nicely in the back too. I think it was smart to have the little wedges that allow&nbsp
column4: the carbonite&nbsp
column5: to slide in easily, but require some effort to pull&nbsp
column6: it out. The one thing that would have been nice to have is some extra space for a prisoner or ally--but ultimately, it's not a big deal.

column1: The build was a lot of fun and nice and long with very little repetition. I didn't have any flimsiness issues or pieces falling off during the build like others mentioned. I have not had any experience building anything like the missile firing system, so that was especially cool to see come together. Like everyone else, I don't really like stickers, but the Mandalorian skull is pretty cool. There seemed to be a good diversity of pieces--including many you don't see very often.

column2: mini-figs in this set really&nbsp
column3: shine. Boba Fett is amazing--way better than past versions. Han is pretty standard for a Han, but the carbonite piece is top notch. My favorite, though, is Bossk.&nbsp
column4: His&nbsp
column5: regular figure was a favorite as a kid, so that may have something&nbsp
column7: He's a great rival for Boba. I team him up with an IG-88 droid from another set.

column1: Anyway, I highly recommend this set! I also recommend, but not
column2: quite as highly, playing the&nbsp
column3: My Backpack's Got Jets"" song on loop while building.

column2: This version of Boba is awesome, Bossk is pretty cool, Han Solo is always cool, and the carbon-frozen Solo is way cool! Building the ship was fun, and it's also cool. One cool part is that it has all the weapon systems that were used in both episode 5 and even episode 2! The set even comes with extra gear that Boba can wear during flight (it's clone commander gear)! This set easily gets a 5/5. &nbsp
column3: &nbsp

column1: The new Bounty Hunters are superb. The new Bossk mini-figure is well done, and exclusive to this set. Bosskâ€™s head is made of hard plastic, which is nice because the rubber kind loses the paint details much faster. Boba Fett is pure awesomeness. The color scheme and body parts are much better than the older version. The only problem is that his antenna keeps falling off. Both Bossk and Boba would get a 9/10.

The Slave I is pretty good, but there are some problems. The dark brown on 6209 looks better than the reddish brown. Instead of a detailed cockpit, Lego used a simple 2x3 plate and a control panel! Why didnâ€™t they make it like the cockpit in 7153? Just in behind the cockpit is a flick-fire missile rack. It works, but the torpedo launcher 6209 works a heck of a lot better. Also, the plates on the bottom keep falling off. On top of that, the model is $20.00 overpriced based on the piece count! However, the ship isnâ€™t all bad. The instructions are easy to understand and the model is fun to build. It also has a lot of unique pieces and great playability. Although there are some problems, it deserves a 7/10.
All together this set is 24/30 or 4 stars and, yes, I would recommend this set to a friend.

DrOrrery","2011-04-23T03:09:39.217Z","So close to perfection","First off, let me say I think this a very good set with a lot of playability. &nbsp
column2: It looks the part and is full of little hidden nooks and crannies, bristling with weapons or hiding spots for the extra pieces of armour that come with Boba Fett. &nbsp
column3: They have been very generous with Boba, given him a cloak as well as his backpack, and all of the visors and other pieces of armour that go with the Episode I-III troops (I haven't got any I-III sets so it took me a long time to work out what all of these extra pieces were). &nbsp
column4: The build is fun, the ship is solid and has excellent whooshability.&nbsp
column5: I have, how ever, two niggles that I find slightly annoying, more so given how close this set was to perfect.
column6: The first is the struts on the side wings. &nbsp
column7: Only one of these struts is actually attached to the ship, the other is just free floating. &nbsp
column8: With a couple of extra pieces I'm pretty sure they could have attached both struts. &nbsp
column9:
Having one floating free is both aesthetically displeasing and makes the wings more fragile than they need to be.

The second niggle is the cockpit.
column11: It's great the way the chair swivels with the wings, but the chair in this case is a 2x3 block with a 2x1 printed tile on it. &nbsp
column12: There is a lot of space in the cockpit, enough for a 4x4 at least. &nbsp
column13: I'd say this is a case of the model falling foul of the price bracket that lego wanted this piece to fall into. &nbsp
column14: Both these issues can be addressed by adding some extra pieces to the build, which I will probably do. &nbsp
column15:
But generally I don't like adding things, it's much more satisfying when the model feels complete out of the box.

Just on the torpedo firing system, I've seen that some people like it, others not so much.
column16: I'm in the like camp, but regardless of what you think about the use of space, this is the first of these torpedoes I've encountered that really works (note, I haven't bought too many Star Wars sets, so maybe I'm just unaware of others). &nbsp
column17: Open the torpedo doors and start firing and all four go straight and true. &nbsp
column18:
Then of course you need to get on your hands and knees to recover them from under the couch :)

Overall I'm very glad I bought this set and would recommend it if you're an original trilogy fan.
column19: It is a tad expensive, so get it on sale if possible. &nbsp

column1:
wander099,"2011-04-25T09:38:29.8Z","Incredible!","

Bear in mind when reading this review that this is the only version of Slave I that I have ever had, so I cannot make comparisons to previous versions.

Box/Instructions

The box for this set is large, I think Lego could have easily made it smaller.
column2: The parts come in three numbered bags and there are two instruction manuals.&nbsp
column3: I think the two manuals was excessive, it should have been one.

column1:
Parts

This set comes with a lot of unique parts and I think that factors in to the price being so high.
column2: For one thing there is a very large cockpit piece that I cannot imagine that Lego has used for much, if anything, else.&nbsp
column3: Of course, the best piece is the carbonite Han Solo which, judging from pictures, is a vast improvement over previous sets.&nbsp
column4:
It is larger and molded as opposed to printed.

One complaint though, there are a fair number of stickers and they are not of good quality.
column5: I have had this model for only a couple of months and already they have to be pushed back down on some of the pieces.&nbsp
column6:
This is much worse than the other models I have.

Minifigures
column7:
>Han Solo:

This is a new version of Han, however with the white shirt and brown pants it is very similar to the figure included in Jabba's Sail Barge (6210).
column8: The main difference is that there is more detail on the shirt.&nbsp
column9: He has the same expression as all the other Han Solo minifigures.
column10:
>Boba Fett:

This is a brand new Boba and it is amazing.
column11: His helmet is printed with loads of detail and though there is a bit of a space between it and his shoulders, that space allows his head to rotate with the helmet on, so it's alright.&nbsp
column12: His torso has front printing and the jetpack accessory is quite detailed.&nbsp
column13: He also has a partial cape and a gun.&nbsp
column14: The gun does look a bit silly with the grey piece on the end, but that is an easy fix.&nbsp
column15: Either remove it, replace it with an extra piece in black, or just use a gun from another set.
column17: Right now this figure is exclusive, but I have a feeling Lego will make at least one other set with him.&nbsp
column18: His head is really nicely sculpted and painted and his torso has front and back printing.

column1:
The build

The build is pretty decent for a set with this many pieces.
column2: There are some more complicated aspects involving the missile firing system, but nothing a builder with a decent amount of experience couldn't handle.&nbsp
column3: Some of the stickers are really hard to place though and some of them have to be aligned perfectly (the ones on the front of the ship) or else they won't match and it will look bad.

column1:
The completed model

This model is quite large, I was impressed with the size, and the colours are quite accurate to the movie.
column2: Playability in this set is really good.&nbsp
column3: When you pick up the ship and hold it vertically, the wings automatically adjust, just like in the movie.&nbsp
column4: The firing mechanism takes up a lot of space, but it works really well.&nbsp
column5: I actually really like the way it was designed.&nbsp
column6: There are some other flick-fire missiles, but even though I don't care for flick fire as a rule, they are movie accurate and I do appreciate it that they were included.&nbsp
column7:
It is true that there is nowhere for Bossk to sit, but he is a rival of Boba's so there is no reason he would be in his ship anyway.

What I don't like about this model is the lack of storage space.
column8: There are very few compartments and there is not room to store the extra armour bits you get.&nbsp
column9: I was very disappointed with this aspect of the model.&nbsp
column10: There could also be a little more room in the back so Han in carbonite was secured better, he keeps sliding forward and it really annoys me even though he doesn't actually fall out.

column1:
Summary

It's a nice ship, but this set is very expensive.
column2: You get 573 pieces for $110 CDN, which is I think one of the worst prices for a Star Wars set I have seen here.&nbsp
column3: Maybe if you are a huge Boba Fett fan you would be willing to pay full price for this set, but I am not.&nbsp
column4: My advice is to wait for a sale if you want this ship.&nbsp
column5: I paid about $80 CDN for this because there was a deal at TRU that if you buy any two Star Wars sets you get 25% off your order.&nbsp
column6:
Without that deal I would never have bought this.

",TRUE,5,5,5,5,3

column1:
badgustav,"2011-01-03T10:42:31.647Z","Dragged me back into Lego after 25 years","Since i was 15, I've occasionally been given or picked up a small Lego set, usually something from Castles or Pirates. My nephew, however, is a massive Lego fan and so we picked him up Darth Vader's tie Fighter (8017) for X-mas. I admit I was intrigued and, being a long time Star Wars fan, it reminded me of the action figure version I had as a kid. So it was that I found myself at Target picking up this set. Now I seem to have the bug!

This set has a lot going for it. Aside from Slave 1 being one of the most unique spaceships designed for a sci-fi movie, Boba Fett is quite the star himself. Add in Han, Han in Carbonite, and Bossk (kind of an odd choice as he was Boba's competition, but still cool) and the set is already fun before you ever build it. That said, as my first ""real"" set in over 15 years, this one kept my interest, showed of the ingenuity of the Lego designers, and challenged me for somewhere around 5 or 6 hours of build time. Once completed, I could not resist flying it around the house and shooting missiles at the cat and dog. My wife thought I was a little off my nut, but she indulged me.

Pros
+ clear instructions, which I'm learning all Lego sets seem to have now
+ great mini-figs
+ Very true to both the movie and the old toy. The fact that the ""wings"" rotate to remain parallel to the ground is great, and the mechanics of it truly impressive
+ build was challenging but not overly so. I suspect the more sets I build, the less challenging I'll find it, but it was just the right mix to start
+ Really solidly built. I can hand it to anyone without worrying I'll have to piece it back together!

Cons
- a few too many of the ""specialized"" pieces that may not help out when I start building original stuff
- Like some here, I prefer the old printed Lego pieces to the stickers. They can be a pain to line up

All in all, a really nice set to lure me back in

",TRUE,5,4,5,5,4

HarlockBrick,"2011-06-23T11:15:28.853Z","A difficult design to translate in bricks...","Many versions of the Slave have been released in the past years, everyone with positive and negative sides.

This latest version has a more desaturated color palette, some interesting minifigs for those who collect them, an interesting windshield (even tho its fixed and doesnt slide open to insert the pilot).

The pilot sits in a completely empty cockpit since the launching missile system takes up all the space inside.

As mentioned above, the color palette is less saturated but compared with the movie or even the animated series its far from correct.

Unfortunately the overall feeling is of a hasted done job.

For a maximum of 75 euro its worth getting it for display purpose, for higher prices think twice... or wait a few years for the next Slave redesign...

dragon_teenager,"2012-02-10T11:46:27.877Z","One of my favorite OT sets.","I've been attracted to this set since its release in 2010, but the hefty price tag kept me away from it. Recently, I was able to score this and the Hoth Wampa Cave for a decent price, and I have them both sitting on my desk. Although I don't have any of the earlier versions of the Slave I, I can tell you that the set is an immensely satisfying build and an excellent display piece.

The first thing you'll build are the minifigures, which for some, are probably the selling point of the set. It's easy to see why - they are excellent. Han Solo looks great, with a nice printed body and his trademark smirk. Bobba Fett looks awesome, including a jetpack, helmet, and fantastic printed body. He also includes a bag of ""gear"" that I remember being included with some Clone Wars sets. Besides for a comm antennae, you'll probably ignore these accessories as they look totally out of place on Bobba. Bossk is also fantastic, with some great back printing and a new mold for the head. All three minifigures included with this set are exclusives (they better be for $79.99!).

Another noteworthy inclusion is a new mold for frozen Han Solo's carbonate. On it's own, it's a great piece, but Han Solo can be placed inside the brick for added playability. It's a great feature that pleasantly surprised me. I believe this same carbonate brick is being included with this Summer's Jabba's Palace set.

Now on to the model itself. In a word, it's great. The building experience is one of the most satisfying I've had in a long time. A huge number of sloped pieces and smart construction make the set sturdy, sleek, and heavy on SNOT techniques. It's also quite large - much larger than I was expecting. In a way, it's size is a bit of a drawback, since it can be difficult to play with. (I still manage.)

I've heard some complaints regarding the colors of the 2010 Slave I. Apparently, they're much too vibrant. Personally, I don't mind it in the least - it makes the model look new, and doesn't hurt the aesthetics at all. I imagine the movie version was more ""faded"" only because it was an older paint job, and this is intended to be a hot-off-the-line bounty hunter hotrod. Unless you're an accuracy purist, I doubt the colors will bother you much. I didn't even notice until I read the complaints.

There are a couple of ""play"" features in the 2010 Slave I. The wings along the side of the vessel are controlled by gravity, meaning that they'll swivel depending on how you're holding the ship. It works well enough, but they do tend to dangle a bit during play. A bigger problem is the cockpit - Bobba's seat is supposed to swivel with the wings, but his antennae accessory prevents the wings from swiveling all the way back during ""flight"" mode. To me, this seems like a huge design oversight! The cockpit itself is pretty weak, too - there's nothing to indicate a chair at all. I would be happier with a more detailed cockpit and less articulated wings.

That is the biggest issue with the set, however. Nothing else seems to stand out. There are ""rapid fire"" flick fire missiles hidden in the chest of the vessel, and you'll be surprised to know that they work quite well. Much better than the standard-issue flick fire missiles, although those are also included in another hidden compartment. The carbonate brick can be stored beneath a boarding ramp in the rear of the vessel, which is nice.

My favorite part about this set is the overall look of it. It appears very nicely proportioned, and aside from the colors, very movie accurate. The secret weapon systems are very cool and cleverly disguised. Although it only includes three minifigures, they are all exclusive to this set, which makes it a very nice buy.

The biggest problem is the price. At $79.99 for 573 parts, it's a tough sell. If you can find it for $59.99 or lower, I would HIGHLY recommend you pick it up! The set is just outstanding, especially if you haven't owned one of the previous versions of the Slave I. However, for the retail price I am on the fence. $79.99 is a lot of money that could be spent on other things. If you have the cash available, and don't have the older Slave I, then this set is for you. Otherwise, you could be forgiven for giving this set a pass.

8.5/10 - Recommended
",TRUE,4,5,5,4,3

KLOKRIECHER,"2012-03-10T06:15:12.313Z","LEGO Star Wars - Slave I Review","

This is a fun set to have and it's fun to play with as wel.

Box/Instructions

This set has two instructions and there're no mistakes in it.

Parts

This set has 573 pieces and for 79.99 USD I think it was really worth the money - even if it is 14 cents per piece. We get a lot of nice molds like the new carbonite piece which looks really detailed to the movie and it's very amazing, too. We also ge a nice big windscreen piece and a new head mold for Bossk which comes in it's own little bag. The're also a lot of other cool small and big pieces in this set which are always great to have.

Minifigures

The minifigs are very nice, too. Han Solo has a very nice looking shirt and his face looks really nice, too. Bossk is one of the new figures. He has never been made before and he looks very detailed as well. The head looks very cool and it's very easy to adjust it full 360Â°. Boba Fett is one of my favourite figures in this set. I'm really impressed how detailed this figure is. The helmet piece has very nice markings and the torso has much better markings than the ones on the older Boba Fett versions. The face looks very nice, too.

The build

This set took me a while but it was a lot of fun to build it. We also get a few stickers with this set. This set has some really interesting techniques like the feature where you can push the flick-missiles.

The completed model

[img]http://www.klokriecher.de/gallery_pics/l/8097-1.jpg[/img]


The completed model is very awsome. The windscreen can be opened and you have a look in the inside of the cockpit. If you move this vehicle into flight mode the cockpit and the wings will adjust. The're also a place where you can hide two flick-missiles on the front and the turrets can be moved as well. The ramp has a place where you can hide the carobnite, too. On each side is a container and between the container where you can see the flick-missiles and the turrets is a part where you can push a container out. On the front you can also see a place which can be opened and where you can see a lot of flick-missiles, too. You can push those if you hit the button on the back of the Slave I where you can see the very detailed engine. I really love the design of this model and I have to say that the details on it are very amazing, too. I may don't have the older versions of this set but I have to say that this is the BEST Slave I LEGO made so far.
in all this set is an great set and I would HIGHLY recommend you to get
this. You can find this set on eBay, BrickLink and Amazon for sure.
Here is the link where you can check out the full gallery I made for this set

column1:
HikerCZ,"2013-03-20T09:09:45.357Z","A true Star Wars classic","My first Slave ship and for a third incarnation not bad at all. Some people might complain about the colour scheme being too vibrant, however, in the movies the ship had gone through quite a lot of beating, so a new ship would have probably looked just like that. Other than that the design is superb and the ship looks excellent from all angles (even the bottom).

A major improvement over the older model is the carbonite version with minifig Han Solo - the design and the fact you can actually place the minifig inside was one of the reasons I got the set (and if you don't intend to buy Jabba's Palace, the only chance to have it). Other minifigs look perfect as well, Boba Fett has a great face under the helmet.

Another positive feature is high playability. The whole concept with firing missiles is very clever and must be a thrill for kids to engage in all kinds of battles.

The drawbacks are not too many to mention, nevertheless in my case the cockpit cover doesn't hold properly so if you grab the ship by it, it stays in your hand. Also one of my stickers was bent and tends to peel off. And for some people this is the major problem - the price is quite high - obviously because of some exclusive molds - so my advice is to get it on sale as I did and it was a bargain.

To sum up, Slave I is an iconic ship and if you're a fan of SW, you won't be disappointed. If you already have the previous model, you can skip this one.
",TRUE,5,5,5,5,4

Bricky_Dee_Williams,"2014-07-23T12:43:49.45Z","Bounty Hunters!","

I got this set as a gift for Christmas 2010, and it was the second biggest set I got, which means it was the second one I built! And I was amazed with the finished product! This latest version of Boba Fett'
column2: s&nbsp
column3: spaceship, once his father&#39
column4: s. I want to first say the set inventory does not disappoint, with many light greens, dark reds, &nbsp
column5: greys and tans. The minifigures are great additions to the set, and the set itself is big enough for them all.&nbsp

column1: The set came in a box depicting the scene in Cloud
column2: City, with the ship flying in its upright position, firing lasers out of I it&#39
column3: s rotating laser cannons at the bottom. The instructions, which there are two of them, are pretty even, with the first book covering wing flaps and interior design, along with the bottom of the ship and basic infrastructure. The second book covers the top building of the ship, the main covering for the interior. They&#39
column4: re pretty easy to follow, and the steps are mainly easy and short.

column1: As I said before, the parts come in a great variety of colors, some more than others. We get new rounded, semi-angled pieces in dark green, many sloped bricks in dark red, and of course the classic Slave I windshield cover piece from the last couple. We also get the brand new Han Solo in Carbonite piece, redesigned for the set so Han can fit under it. We also get pieces like the flaps on the front of the wings, which are held in by the "
column2: click&quot
column3: elevation system, and many others including curved edge pieces as seen on the front, that also make up the ship&#39
column4: s bottom.

column1: There are three new and mainly exclusive minifigures, seen for the first time in this set:
-Boba Fett: So far this is the fifth version of. Boba, counting the White Boba, young Boba, original Boba, and the rare Boba with printed arms and
column2: legs. He comes with a new Star Wars accessory bag, wich includes pistols, armor, and helmet coms. His helmet, for the first time ever, is not connected to his jetpack, which is a new helmet piece. He comes in much nicer light green and grey, with a new torn and tattered dark red-brown shred of a cape. He also comes with a Star Wars gun from the last few years that includes a technic piece on the end.

column1: -Bossk: First seen in this set, Bossk
column2: is an all new minifigure. He has a specially molded head piece,an exclusive torso piece, and yellow legs with a light grey connecting piece in between. The torso is made to represent Bossk&#39
column3: s space suit from The Empire Strikes Back, and Bossk&#39
column4: s weapon included in the set is a long barreled Star Wars rifle.

column1: -Han Solo: Not really much to say about Han, as he has dark brown legs, a rumpled white shirt for a torso, and his classic hair and head piece. However, Han'
column2: s niche in the set is to clip into the brand new Carbonite piece, which fits minifigures perfectly, but his gave is different. In the Carbonite piece, his face is twisted with pain, but asleep. He appears in set 9516 with a sleepy face matching the Carbonite piece expression.

column1: The build takes less than two hours, maybe about one and a half. There aren'
column2: t many technic functions except on the bottom and then one on the top for the blue-tipped&nbsp
column3: missile compartment. It is end rally easy, adding just a few pieces at a time. This version has some pieces that are fragile and fall of easy, which is a distraction in the course of building the set. The way to avoid this is to make sure the pieces are securely interlocked with the piece they rest on.

column1: The completed model is smaller than expected, but altogether wonderful. The guns on the end of the ship swivel practically 360 degrees, and the missiles behind them fold out to come out of their little compartment,
column2: which has folding doors that open downwards. The cockpit windshield piece comes off easily, and Boba and Bossk fit nicely into the compartment, Boba in the seat with the controls, and Bossk sitting behind at the front of the ship. The missile launching system, hidden in the interior middle of the ship, works and functions nicely, with a stud attached at the end so the technic piece dogs not slip out after all four missiles are deployed. The wings on the sides roll back and forth in when you tip the spaceship upward, as if it were really flying. I am very pleased with the completed model.&nbsp

column1: Verdict: Get it, especially if you are a Star Wars fan.

I, as I believe others are, feel this set is absolutely great. The set is a semi-easy build, and amounts to a set better than other versions before it. Also, the rare colored pieces go great with any collection.
column2: Unlike other Star&nbsp
column3: Wars&nbsp

column5: t fail to disappoint. The trio of minifigures go well with the set, and all fit in nicely. Which reminds me. Han in Carbonite is tucked into the cargo bay on the back of the ship. He fits very well in the ship too. The set has far more cons than pros, so here they are.
